loans.name: Lucena

texts.en: Lucena is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines with her husband and nine children. For the last two years, she has earned a living by selling firewood. She is applying for a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy more firewood to sell to her customers. She has been a member of HSPFI since 2008 and is committed to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy more firewood to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Janette Maribel

texts.es: Janette Maribel D. cuarenta y seis años D. edad vive junto a su hija, la cual aun asiste a la escuela. Ella posee un comedor y pupuseria en el lugar donD. resiD., con el que sostiene su hogar, ya tiene varios años con el negocio y últimamente tiene más demanda, pues la zona es muy concurrida D. personas además que prepara los platillos más exquisitos pollo, carne asada, arroz, sopas, ensaladas, pupusas entre otros, todo es preparado con material D. calidad y lo venD. a precios accesibles; Janette siempre ha sido una mujer muy servicial y le gusta mucho su trabajo, tiene muchas metas pues planea tener un futuro triunfante, ella piensa que el mundo está en manos D. aquellos que tienen el coraje D. soñar, es así como se decidió a solicitarle a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar carnes, verduras, granos básicos, queso, chicharrón, bebidas etc. Janette tiene la confianza que con su esfuerzo podrá darle a su familia una mejor calidad D. vida.
texts.en: Janette Maribel, 46, lives with her daughter who attends school still.  She has an eatery and pupusa [corn cakes] shop at home that is her source of household support.  She’s been in business several years now and lately demand has increased because the zone is very crowded with people and she prepares the most delicious dishes: chicken, grilled meat, rice, soups, salads and pupusas, among others.  Everything is prepared with quality ingredients and she sells it at affordable prices.  Janette has always been a very service oriented person and she likes her work very much.  She has many goals for she expects to have a successful future.  She believes that the world is there for those who dare to dream.  This is how she decided to ask INTEGRAL for a loan to buy meats, vegetables, basic grains, cheese, fried pork skin, beverages, etc.  Janette trusts that with her effort she’ll be able to proviD. her family with a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, cheese, fried pork and beverages.

loans.name: Nasitazi

texts.en:
In all appearances farming is 44 year old Nasitazi's business. It has been his business for three years now. The father of five, as noted in the picture, mostly grows plantains, beans, maize and Irish potatoes.
It's through the sale of these crops that he makes his wherewithal to sustain and provide for his family.
This business generates him sales weekly revenue to the tune of UGX 20,000.
He intends to use his Kiva loan to purchase manure to apply in his farms.

loans.use: to purchase manure to apply in his farms.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman and she is 18 years of age, with one child.

Mary owns and operates a business venture, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community.  She has three years of experience in this business.  Mary needs a loan of WST 2000 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2009, Mary joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Mary's fifth loan with SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: 23 De Marzo Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “23 DE MARZO”  iniciará el segundo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Monica es la Tesorera. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos tenemos: venta de verduras, tejido de mantas, venta de bañadores y baldes, venta de pipocas de maíz, venta de ropa coreana, costura de faldas, venta de coca.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Monica es integrante, ella indica que hace siete meses que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de su suegra que es socia de la institución.  En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de coca que trabaja hace años atrás, cuenta que en la actualidad su familia desarrolla este cultivo en los Yungas y que ella lo trae  a La Paz para la venta.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de taqui de coca) que adquirirá de sus vecinas de su comunidad y posteriormente lo comercializará en los mercados autorizados. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para apoyar en lo posible a su familia, pues ella vive en unión libre y tiene un hijo.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de salud.
texts.en:
The communal bank “23 de Marzo” will begin their second cycle in Pro Mujer as part of the “Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación.”  It is composed of eight members and is directed by a board of directors where Monica is the treasurer.  The businesses that the members of the communal bank have are varied, among them:  vegetable sales, blanket weaving, sales of bath items, popcorn sales, Korean clothing sales, skirt sewing and the selling of coca.

The loan that they take out will benefit the small-business entrepreneurs where Monica is a member.  She explains that she joined Pro Mujer seven months ago, entering at the invitation of her mother-in-law who is a member of the institution.  At present she has a business selling coca that she has worked at for years.  She says that currently her family carries out this cultivation in the Yungas and that she brings it to La Paz to sell. 

The loan that she will take out now is for the increase of capital for the purchase of a “taqui” (equivalent to 50 pounds) of coca that she will acquire from her neighbors in her community and that she will subsequently sell in the authorized markets.  This form of work permits her to generate resources in order to support her family as much as possible, as she lives in a common-law marriage and has one child. 

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the health services.

loans.use: to buy a “taqui” of coca.

loans.name: Rince

texts.en: Rince is a 41 year old woman, is married to Simon (52) and has 5 children. Simon is a village officer with a small salary, therefore Rince initiated a selling cakes business 2 years ago to help her pay for her 1st child tuition fees as well as the other children. In order to increase the amount of cakes she sells as well the business income, Rince joined with another member and get loan from TLM of amounting IDR 2,000,000. This business would help Rince to pay for more cakes ingredients such as wheat flour, cooking oil, and also kitchen utilities such as wok, spatula, stove etc. With the help of TLM, Rince will no longer sell cakes door to door however, she would like to sell it in front of her house. She is hoping that the business will grow well so she can pay the loan to TLM right on time.

loans.use: to pay for more cakes ingredients such as wheat flour, cooking oil, and also kitchen utilities such as wok, spatula, stove etc.

loans.name: Kem

texts.en:
This business is located in Thnot Chum Village, Boengtumpun Commune, Min Chey District just outside of Phnom Penh City.

Kem P. is living with her husband, four children and mother-in-law in a small, two storeys wooden house. Their main activity consists in growing and harvesting water spinach in the nearby fields. The household production is brought to the market in a motorbike cart they have to rent every day, and sold in the market for human and animal consumption.

With the $700 she will receive from CREDIT, Kem P. want to buy the motorbike cart for $120 to save the money of the daily rent. She is also planning to increase her crops through renting one more hectare of land, which is worth $200 yearly. P. will have to purchase more seeds, for $1.25 per 10 square meters, and she knows she will have to work harder with her husband but they expect to increase their annual income over the next few years.

P. is not satisfied with this business: they can barely earn their living with it, she said. Her plan is to spare enough money to open a stand in the market, and sell her neighbors production. In that case, her husband could become a moto-taxi.

loans.use: Buying a motorbike cart

loans.name: Aimée

texts.en:
Married and mother of three (3) children, Mrs Aimée AGOUSSOU has a business buying and selling "sodabi", a local drink made with palm oil. Her husband is a subsistance farmer because of his rudimentary tools. Mrs AGOUSSOU is a woman who fights for the well-being of her children. To have a large clientele she looks for quality in her products. In view of her experience and her dynamism, she has already benefited from two loans which she paid back with no difficulty. Wanting to reinforce her business, she is asking for a new loan of $700 that she will use as business capital for the purchase and sale of Sodabi. This loan will be benefical because it will increase her level of revenue and allow her to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Susan Bell, Kiva Volunteer.

Mariée et mère de trois (3) enfants, Madame A. Aimée a pour activité principale l’achat et la revente de « sodabi », boisson locale fabriquée à base du palmier à huile. Son mari est un cultivateur qui pratique une agriculture de subsistance à cause du caractère rudimentaire des outils. Madame A. Aimée est une femme qui se bât beaucoup pour la réussite de ses enfants. Pour avoir une clientèle importante, elle recherche la qualité de ses produits. Vu son expérience et son dynamisme, elle a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qu’elle a remboursé sans aucune difficulté. Voulant renforcer son activité, elle sollicite un nouveau crédit de $700 qui va lui servir de fonds de commerce pour l’achat et la revente de Sodabi. Ce crédit lui sera bénéfique puisqu’il a rehaussé son niveau de revenu et permettre ainsi d’améliorer le niveau de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: buy and sell sodabi

loans.name: Galina

texts.en:
Galina is married and has one grown daughter. For a while she worked as a trolley-bus controller selling tickets to passengers. She also worked part-time as a market vendor. However, Galina wanted to be self-employed, so six years ago she decided to start her own business. Today she has four market vending facilities – two selling dishware sets and ceramics, and two locations selling clothing and shoes. She has hired several employees who help her with sales.

Galina realizes that lending services have been the engine pushing her business forward. The seventeen loans she has received and repaid from “Nadiya Ukraine” have helped her business grow. With financial assistance Galina was able to purchase two more vending facilities and hire two people to work for her. Currently, she has about $8,000 in inventory. Her monthly gross revenue amounts to $2,000.

Galina has requested a loan of $1,200 to open her fifth vending facility and start selling dishware and ceramic goods in a new location. She is planning to buy tableware, dinnerware and porcelain sets at wholesale prices that she can re-sell in her new kiosk. Galina is hoping that the expansion of her trade will help her meet high demand for dishware and boost her sales.

Галина – одружена, в неї є доросла дочка. Певний час вона працювала контролером в тролейбусі. Потім змінила місце роботи, почала працювати на ринку реалізатором. Проте, Галина хотіла працювати на себе. Отже, 6 років тому вона вирішила почати власну справу. Зараз в неї 4 торгові точки: два кіоски з продажу посуду та кераміки, два – з продажу одягу та взуття. В роботі Галині допомагають декілька реалізаторів. Галина розуміє, що кредитні послуги – це той двигун, який штовхає її вперед. Сімнадцять позик, які вона отримала від „Надії України” сприяли розвитку її бізнесу. Завдяки фінансовій підтримці Галина змогла придбати дві торгові точки та взяти на роботу ще двох реалізаторів. Зараз в неї приблизно 8000 доларів в товарі. Її щомісячний валовий дохід складає 2000 доларів. Галина просить про позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб відкрити п’яту торгову точку з продажу посуду та керамічних виробів. Вона планує закупити посуд, порцелянові набори за оптовими цінами для подальшої роздрібної торгівлі в новому кіоску. Галина сподівається, що розширення бізнесу допоможе їй задовольнити попит на посуд та підвищить обсяги продажів.

loans.use: To open a new vending facility

loans.name: Gaby

texts.es:
Gaby's husband, like many bolivian women's, left her to fill the roles of both mother and father to her three children who are 6,7 and 2 years old. She has been working as a mechanic and has been a pioneer in this field, which is normally dominated by men. She is also a professional taxi driver, from which she derives the majority of her income to support her family.

Gaby lives in her parents' home at 15th Street of Agosto, number 2475 in the Zona Fatravi in the town El Alto.

The loan will be used to purchase a motor for her car, which she uses to transport her customers ( aTrufi). A "Trufi" is similar to a taxi service, the only difference being trufis have a pre-planned and fixed route.

This is her third loan, her timely repayments of her previous loans makes her a good candidate for another and she hopes to repair her car so that she can continue working without any problems. Her repayment history is satisfactory from her previous 18 repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Kiva Volunteer, Kristin Connor.

Gaby, como muchas mujeres bolivianas ha sido abandonada por su esposo quedando como padre y madre de sus tres hijos de 6,7 y 2 años de edad; ella ha tenido la necesidad de trabajar como mecánico y pionera en una actividad que normalmente es desempeñada por varones y tiene una movilidad que trabaja con un chofer, de donde se derivan sus ingresos principales con los que mantiene a su familia. Gaby vive en la casa de sus padres ubicada en la calle 15 de Agosto # 2475 de la Zona Fatravi en la Ciudad de El Alto. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de un motor para su movilidad, que trabaja de servicio público (Trufi).Para un mejor conocimiento un “Trufi” es muy similar a un taxi, con la única diferencia que los trufis tienen una ruta fija. Es el tercer crédito que recibe de nuestra Institución; su buen comportamiento de pago en los dos créditos anteriores le permite acceder a otro préstamo y mejorar la condición de su vehiculo para que trabaje sin problema. El análisis de su flujo de caja muestra condiciones satisfactorias para el repago del crédito en las 18 cuotas que solicita.

loans.use: To purchase a motor for her car.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: "I am 34 years old, married with 6 children. I have been an LAPO member for 6 years," says Mrs. Theresa, who sells drinks, garri and vegetables to those living in her community. She needs the above loan to buy more drinks, garri and vegetables to sell in her store.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, pure water & food stuffs

loans.name: Tania

texts.es:
Tania has a small stall and sells groceries and other household products in the central market of León. She has had this business for over 20 years. In fact, Mrs. V. has been selling products in the market all of her life. Her mother had a small stall in the same market and Tania helped her until she got married. Her husband passed away and now Tania has to cover 100% of her family's needs because she still has three single and young children. She obtained part of the capital to start her business through savings and the other portion was through loans. She also got a small amount of merchandise from her mother, who closed down her own business.

Through her hard work, she was able to put her three children through professional school. Her son is an electrical engineer, one of her daughters has a degree in business administration and her other daughter has a degree in Turism and hospitality. Tania has been working with CEPRODEL for over three years and has an excellent loan record.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio es un pequeño puesto de venta de abarrotes y otros productos del hogar ubicado en el mercado central de León, el cual tiene más de 20 años de existir. De hecho la señora V. se ha dedicado toda la vida a vender en el mercado. Su madre poseía un pequeño puesto en el mismo mercado y ella le asistía hasta el momento en el que se casó. Sin embargo, su marido fallece y ella tiene la necesidad de asumir el 100% de la carga del hogar ya que aún tenía hijos solteros y jóvenes. Parte del capital para iniciar el negocio lo obtuvo de unos pequeños ahorros y otro a través de préstamos, además, para aquel entonces su mamá ya iba abandonando el negocio y ella le dejo una pequeña cantidad de mercadería.

Por medio de su esfuerzo, ella logró dar educación profesional a sus tres hijos teniendo un Ing. Electrónico, una hija Lic. En administración de empresas y una Lic. En Administración Turística y Hotelera. Tiene más de tres años de trabajar con CEPRODEL y posee un excelente record crediticio.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoeun V. married in 1991 and has three children: two sons and one daughter. Currently, she is weaving silk at home. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1992, and she started her silk production in the same year. All of her children are studying. Her husband, Mr. Sok Vai, is a fisherman and a boat repairer, too. He fishes every day along the Mekong river around his village and sometimes in the lake. He has finished high school. They both work hard every day to support their children in school, and they hope that all of their children will get high education in the future.

This is her second loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $700. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials and sewing thread, pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom, and buy one boat and a fishing net for her husband.

loans.use: Purchase silk materials and sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom, and one boat and fishing net.

loans.name: Jennifer's Group

texts.en:
Jennifer K. produces about 4 egg trays a day and wishes to take a loan in order to add to her flock, build more poultry houses, and purchase more chicks. She has 5 family members and looks after one orphan.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To increase egg production

loans.name: Ratna Devi

texts.en:
Mrs. Ratna Devi M. Lives in Thecho Village, one of the developing villages of the Lalitpur district of Nepal, where most of people are engaged in farming.
Mrs. M. lives with her husband and two sons. Her elder son is studying in grade 6 and her younger son is only two years old.
Mrs. M. and her husband Mr. Krishna Gopal M. opened their mustard oil store 5 years ago. They buy oil directly from mill and sell it in the local market. 
She is asking for her third loan of Rs 20000 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Dike

texts.en: Dike N. is a single lady, 26 years of age, and hails from the Ojo Igbede area in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a fashion designer and also sells cloth and bakes cakes for sale. She has been with LAPO for the past 2 years and needs a loan of $875 to enable her to buy more cloth for sales.

loans.use: To buy more cloth for sales

loans.name: Buhory

texts.ru:
Buhory K., 71, lives in the city of Yavan. He is married and has seven children. Buhory has a secondary technical education; he was trained as a tractor operator. At present, he does not have a job. He raises goats, sheep, and cattle for a living on his small farmstead. Buhory is applying for a loan to increase the volume of livestock he has and to grow his business. This will help him increase the income he receives from selling calves, and will improve his family's financial situation. Buhory plans to repay the loan within ten months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer.

Кориев Бухори Проживает в городе Яван. Возраст 71 год , женат и имеет 7 детей. Образование средне- техническое , по специальности тракторист. В данный момент нигде не работает , но занимается разведением животных. Имеет хозяйство где разводит коз , овец и бычков. Клиент планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы увеличить поголовье скота и развить свой бизнес. Это поможет ему увеличить доход с продаваемых бычков, а так же поможет улучшить финансовое положение семьи. А погасить кредит клиент планирует в течении 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase calves

loans.name: Lizy

texts.en:
Mambo (Hello!) from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Lizy M.. She is married and has three children, ages 10, 13, and 17.

In 2007, Lizy established her crop wholesaling business. Lizy requires a loan in order to purchase maize, rice, and cocoa crops in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a leading role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. Because customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, the women lack tangible collateral assets, and financial institutions do not consider them to be credit-worthy. This leads to poor financial support and, as a result, limited access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys the equipment from the client, extends a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a "sale and leaseback" arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase maize, rice, and cocoa, in bulk.

loans.name: Faavae

texts.en:
Faavae F., 58, is married with 5 children. Her husband is one of the chief council members of her village. She has 5 years of experience in the taro and bananas business. She sells to the village community at the Fugalei market 3 days per week.

She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 350 Tala (~145 USD). SPBD loans are Faavae’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase replacement equipment for her business. Part of the loan will also be used to support her children's school expenses.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 43 year-old Filomena A.. She is married and has four children aged between 4 and 21. She also has two dependents who live with her because one is an orphan whose parents have passed away with HIV/AIDS, and the other has parents who live in a remote area, where it is difficult to attend school.

In 2007, Filomena established her traditional African cloth business. Working seven days a week and 9 to 12 hours a day, she earns about US $230 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Filomena requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of cloth, dye and other chemicals, which she will use to make a new range of colourful cloth. In the future, Filomena plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of plain cloth, dyes and fabric paint, which she will use to make a new range of colourful batik cloth, as shown in the photo. Filomena is standing on the far right of the photo, which has been shot with her two friends.

loans.name: Matrona

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is 39-year-old Matrona N., who is married and has two children aged 12 and 15. In 2006, Matrona established her used clothing business. Working seven days a week, 10 hours a day, and assisted by her husband and one employee, she earns about $310 every month from this business . Matrona is now requesting a loan in order to purchase an additional stock of used clothing. In the future, she plans to to increase the quantity and range of her stock. She thanks you for your support.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because of their low cost, and the general appeal of anything western or modern. Some argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase an additional stock of used clothes.

loans.name: Elizabeth Koska

texts.es:
Elizabeth is a member of Banco Comunal El Arenal, a communal bank, which is located in Jr Ricardo Palma #577, in the district of Calleria in the region of Ucayali. She is 43 years old and is a mother of 3 children. Her huband is a teacher. Elizabeth invested the first loan of $106 from Manuela Ramos in her food business.

Elizabeth wakes up early everyday to prepare breakfast for her husband who has to go to work with their children who are students. Later, Elizabeth goes to the market so she can prepare the food that she sells in the evenings.

With a loan of $425 that will be repaid in 6 months, she will use it to buy ½ sack of rice, 3 chickens, 4 liters of oil, vegetables, and also do some maintenance on her 2 cars. Elizabeth is grateful to Manuela Ramos' Movement for its support and the accomplishments that has been achieved in her life. She is very happy for the income that she has been able to make for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Elizabeth, pertenece al Banco Comunal El Arenal, ubicado en el Jr Ricardo Palma # 577, del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 43 años es madre de 3 hijos. Su esposo es Docente. Elizabeth con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertir en venta de comida.

Elizabeth se levanta muy temprano todos lo días para preparar el desayuno de su esposo que tiene que ir a trabajar como para sus hijos que tienen que ir a estudiar; para luego Elizabeth pueda ir al mercado a realizar sus compras para que prepara su comida para que salir a vender en las noches.

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,200 el cual será pagado en 6 meses, invertirá en la compra de ½ saco de arroz, 3 pollos, 4 litros de aceite, verduras y también hizo el mantenimiento de sus 2 motokar. Elizabeth, agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por el respaldo brindado, ya que gracias a ello sigue logrando muchos éxitos en su vida y esta muy feliz por los ingresos que puede generar para su familia.

loans.use: Buy supplies at wholesale and maintain her cars

loans.name: Maria Dolores

texts.es:
María Dolores V. D. Laínez vive en el municipio D. Lourdes en el departamento D. La Libertad.  Como madre D. dos hijos, que cursan sus respectivos estudios académicos, María se ve constantemente en la necesidad D. mantener un equilibrio entre sus responsabilidades económicas, y las responsabilidades D. crianza, para con sus hijos.
DesD. hace ya dos años, María Laínez, abrió un pequeño negocio D. Bazar D. ropa. Lastimosamente, su negocio no alcanzó la demanda necesaria, lo que derivó en perdida. María, mediante fe y perseverancia, reconstruyó su negocio, ampliando sus ventas y ofreciendo nuevos productos, como papelería, útiles y ropa interior. María solicita un préstamo para surtir D. productos su nuevo negocio, y comprar nueva mercadería, que le permita darle nueva vida a su microempresa y mejorar la calidad D. su vida familiar.
texts.en:
María Dolores V. D. Laínez lives in the municipality of Lourdes in the department of La Libertad. As a mother of two children who are students, María constantly sees the need to maintain a balance between her economic responsibilities and those of raising her children.

It’s already been two years since María Laínez opened a small clothing shop. Sadly, her shop did not have the needed demand which resulted in loss. María, through faith and perseverance, rebuilt her business, increasing her sales and offering new products, like stationery, tools, and underwear. María requests a loan to stock products in her new business and to buy new merchandise that will allow her to give a new life to her enterprise and to improve the quality of her family’s life.

Translated from Spanish by Joanna Silverman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and products for the store

location.town: Lourdes Colón, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Saul

texts.es: Saúl tiene 42 años y vive solo.  Trabaja en las labores de la cerrajería, tiene un taller y ofrece servicios de fabricación de puertas, ventanas y demás objetos de metal, con este taller, ya lleva más de un año y medio. Además, también es músico, por lo que todos los fines de semana, realiza presentaciones para todo evento social, es integrante de una banda musical, de esta manera, puede sostenerse y disfruta cada día de lo que realiza, por lo que seguirá adelante.  Su motivación de trabajo es sobresalir y mejorar cada vez, su calidad de vida.   Solicita este préstamo, con el que podrá adquirir materiales para su taller, los que servirán para cubrir los pedidos que le soliciten.
texts.en:
Saul is 42 and lives alone. He works in a locksmith's shop and offers services of door and window making and other metal work services, he’s had this shop for more than a year and a half. In addition, he is a musician and every weekend has presentations at social events, he is a member of a band, this way he can support himself, enjoy what he does and get ahead. His motivation to work is to get better and improve his quality of life. He requests this loan, with which he will be able to acquire materials for his shop to carry out future orders.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Incrementar los materiales que utiliza en su cerrajería, para el cumplimiento de los pedidos que tiene.

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
Carlos C. C. vive en su vivienda propia en la zona de Pasankeri, área suburbana de esta ciudad con su esposa, la señora Mercedes Arteaga y sus dos hijos.
Carlos trabaja como empleado de la construcción, es contratista independiente, su esposa es ayudante de cocina en un restaurante de la zona.
Debido al desnivel de su propiedad, Carlos ha realizado la excavación de su terreno para nivelar el mismo con la calle.
El crédito solicitado será para la construcción de un muro de contención, esto permitirá estabilizar la vivienda.
Esta es la primera vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente, por lo tanto, puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Carlos C. C. lives in his own home in the Pasankeri zone, a suburban area of this city, with his wife Mercedes Arteaga and his two children.

Carlos works as a construction worker, he is an independent contractor, and his wife works in the kitchen of one of the zone’s restaurants.

Due to the uneven nature of his property, Carlos has excavated his land to make it level with the street.

The loan he is requesting would be used to build a retaining wall, which would allow him to stabilize his house.

This is the first time he seeks a loan, and the socioeconomic analysis conducted qualifies him favorably for access to credit.


Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a retaining wall.

loans.name: Anonymous Group

texts.en:
Eight people in Kroay Wat village in Kampong Chhnang Province have formed a village bank loan group. Mrs. Vandy S. is the village bank president. 

Mrs. S. sells firewood. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more firewood to resell. She hopes to increase her income and improve her living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr. Voeun Chea, is a policeman. Mrs. Vandy S. is 27 years old and the mother of two children who are enrolled in the local school. 

One member of this village bank loan group has an end-of-term (EoT) loan; the rest of have monthly payment loans. The member with the EoT loan is not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product, because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s client make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more firewood to resell.

loans.name: Sinoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sinoeun L. and her husband, Mr. Senghorn Ton, both 49, who live along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married in 1979 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two are married and live outside the family home while the third assists his parents in farming.

Sinoeun and her husband, who also farm, have been selling vegetable pickles for ten years. She is now requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a trailer to transport vegetables for sale.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to carry vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Ama

texts.fr: Cette dame habite le quartier de yokoe  à adidogomé, elle a pour activité le commerce de bissap et de fruits de baobab qui sont des fruits qu'on utilise pour faire du jus de bissaps et de jus de fruits de baobab, son activité marche bien. Elle a besoin d’acheter des fruits pour augmenter son stock, elle n’a jamais obtenu de crédit de chez wages et sollicite son premier crédit d’un montant de 300000F pour pouvoir acheter des bissaps et des fruits de baobab. Elle est mariée et a 04 enfants, ce crédit lui aussi permettra de soutenir sa famille.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Yokoe neighborhood in Adidogomé. Her business is selling "bissap" (hibiscus flowers) and monkey bread (baobab tree fruit), both of which are used in the preparation of juice. Her business is going well. She needs to buy more fruit to complete her stock. She has never before had a loan from WAGES, so she is requesting her first in the amount of 300,000 F to buy hibiscus flowers and monkey bread. She is married and has 4 children; this loan will allow her to better support her family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of hibiscus flowers and monkey bread

loans.name: Bimkubwa

texts.en:
Bimkubwa has been a food seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. 
She belongs to Hatuchokani loan group (Group code 2094).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $400.Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.  

Bimkubwa is 34 years old, married, and has one child: aged 2. She also cares for one additional dependant.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Bich Loan

texts.vi: Chị Loan năm nay 27  tuổi, chị tham gia Quỹ tìnhthương từ năm 2008. Hiện tại hai vợ chồng chị Loan đều tham gia kinh doanh buôn bán hàng khô. Hàng ngày chồng chị đi lấy các loại thực phẩm khô như  cá khô, tôm tép từ các nhà sản xuất về cho chị bán buônn, bán lẻ tại chợ . Công việc kinh doanh đang phát triển tốt và đem lại cho gia đình chị thu nhập 4.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 9.000.000đ để đầu tư cho công việc kinh doanh của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Loan is 27 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 2008. Currently, Mrs. Loan and her husband sell dried goods. Her husband purchases goods such as dried fish and shrimp from factories for her to resell at the market. Her business is growing and brings her family an income of 4,000,000 VND per month. She would like to borrow 9,000,000 VND to invest in her family's business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thiennga Ngo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business

loans.name: Felix

texts.en: Felix is 65 years old and married with six children. He sells motor spare parts.  Felix has been in this business for a long time.  He hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more motor spare parts to sell.  He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more spare parts for motor to sell.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn D. lives in the municipality of Hamtic in beautiful Antique Province. Hamtic is situated to the south of Antique, and is bounded by mountains in one direction and the coast in the other. Evelyn is 38 years old and has two sons and two daughters. Her eldest child, a daughter, is 14 and attends high school; the other three children are still in primary school. Evelyn's husband Alexius is a driver.

Evelyn plans to use the money from this loan to buy inventory for her sari-sari store. "Sari-sari" is Tagalog for "various kinds" and the shops sell just that: an assortment of basic foodstuffs, beverages, and everyday commodities. The shops retail items in small units -- selling single cigarettes, for example. Sari-sari shops fill an important economic and social niche in Filipino life, especially in poor or rural areas; they often have chairs or a bench out front and act as neighborhood watering holes.

Evelyn dreams that one day perhaps she'll be able to grow her sari-sari store into a mini-mart. She hopes that her business will continue to provide her with the income necessary to support her children's education.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her small variety store

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa S. is single and has two children. She has received an education through junior high school. Since 2002, she has sold groceries at Broynbima near Elmina. Theresa uses her income to pay for her family’s electric bill and the children’s school fees. Theresa will use the loan to purchase bags of rice, boxes of tomatoes, and oil. With the new profits from her expanded business, Theresa plans to reinvest in her enterprise.

loans.use: Theresa will use the loan to purchase bags of rice, boxes of tomatoes, and oil.

loans.name: Alejandro Nestor

texts.es: Don Alejandro es casado, de 46 años de edad, con 4 hijos de los cuales 2 estudian y 2 trabajan, su esposa se dedica a los trabajos de la casa.  El trabaja como operador de pozos en ENACAL Acoyapa, con 17 años de servicio, sus turnos son de 12 horas de 6:00 am. a 6:00 pm., tiene un dia libre cada 2 dias.  Esta solicitando su 3er credito para la construccion de una cocina, levantara paredes y pondra techo para de esta manera dar un poco de comodidad a su esposa, ya que con el invierno la situcion se pone un poco dificil.  Sus 2 creditos anteriores los utilizo para remodelar su vivienda, pero no fue suficiente para cumplir con todo lo planificado, por tal razon esta solicitando este nuevo credito para ir cumpliendo con las condiciones necesarias de su vivienda, estos fueron pagados en tiempo y forma.
texts.en:
Don Alejandro is married, 46 years old and has 4 children, two of them students and two working. His wife works in the home. He works as a well operator in ENACAL Acoyapa, where he has 17 years of service. His shifts are 12 hours long, from 6:00 am to 6:00 pm, and he gets a day free every two days. He is requesting his third loan for the construction of a kitchen; he will build walls and put on a roof this way providing a little bit more comfort to his wife, since in the winter the situation gets a bit difficult. The previous two loans he used for the remodel of his home, but they were not enough to satisfy all his plans. He is requesting this loan to be able to go on improving the conditions of his home. The previous loans were properly repaid on time.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of a kitchen.

loans.name: Mavdjuda

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

  Мавджуда Рахмонова 1970 года рождения, замужем имеет 3 детей. Почти всю свою жизнь заниматься откормом скота. Выращивает овец и коров. Более 15 лет ухаживает за скотом. Рано утром скот отправляет с детьми на пастбище для откорма. Скот там пасется до вечера. Муж Мавджуды зарабатывает на жизнь строительством на стройке. 
Первый кредит получила 3 года назад на покупку  корма и несколько овец. Благодаря поддержки КИВА ее дети учатся в приличных школах, а также  она улучшила своё семейное положение.
texts.en:
Mavjuda R. was born in 1970, she is married and has three children. Almost all of her life she has been breeding cattle. She raises sheep and goats and looks after the cattle for more than fifteen years. In the early morning she sends her children to take the cattle to the pastures for feeding. The cattle shepherds there until the evening. Mavjuda's husband earns his living in construction. She has received her first loan three years ago to buy fodder and several sheep. Thanks to the support of Kiva her children are studying in decent schools and she has improved her family's living conditions.

MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy five sheep

loans.name: Loretta

texts.en:
Loretta V., 21, is married with two children. She has many years of experience in the pancake business. She sells to the public and villagers five days per week and expects her weekly net cash flow to be 300 Tala (~125 USD). She has no previous loan with SPBD.

SPBD loans are Loretta’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. She’s thankful for the program and the opportunity she has in getting financial help to assist her family.

loans.use: To purchase equipment and ingredients for making pancakes like flour, sugar, cooking oil and plastic bags

loans.name: Sittinona

texts.en:
Sittinona E. is one of the pioneer members of the CCT Credit Cooperative in her community. She lives with her husband, a jeepney driver and mechanic, and their three school-aged children. Sittinona's family is also one of the earliest recipients of a row-house unit in the Habitat for Humanity Housing Project, in BASECO Compound, Port Area, Manila.

Sittinona started a small general store in 2003. When she joined CCT in 2005, she was able to keep her store going and growing. The store, located at the heart of the Habitat and near the school, caters to customers from all over. Sittinona took advantage of its location near the school by adding school supplies to satisfy the high demand from elementary students at a nearby school. Sittinona will use this loan to expand the inventory in her store.

Just last year, Sittinona received another heaven-sent blessing – she and her husband were able to buy a passenger jeepney, which her husband drives every day. They use their combined income from the store and the jeepney's daily income to support the education of their three children. Sittinona dreams of acquiring another vehicle to transport her inventory from the market.

About CCT
CCT is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered on the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: Inventory for her store

loans.name: Mrs. Vouchnor Hok Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank Group, which consists of 16 people, is located in Tuol Kdei village in Kandal province. Mrs. Vouchnor H. is the Village Bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a fish retailer in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more fish to re-sell to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Tho Thang, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. Mrs. Vouchnor H. is 34 years old and the mother of five children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school, while the others are too young to work or study. 

Four members in this group loA. are End-of-Term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loA. until the very end of the loA. term. End-of-Term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loA. term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more fish for resale

loans.name: Tunda Group

texts.en:
Beatrice is a member of the Tunda borrower group in Msamvu,Morogoro,she is 25 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child.Her child is aged 1 year.

Beatrice started her own food business selling bites 1 year ago,she works 7 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 30,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Beatrice first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities like wheat flower,cooking oil for her business.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Beatrice hopes to save money and expand her business.

Ngusa,Sandra are also the member of the same borrower group,they also requested the loan amount of 200,000 each one in order to expand their business.

loans.use: To buy wheat ,cooking oil

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is thirty-eight years old. She is divorced and has given birth to four children, a son and three daughters, who are all in school. She works very hard to be able to provide for the family. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Konongo in the Ashanti region of Ghana. 

Margaret sells palm oil. She prepares and supplies the oil to retailers and food vendors in her community. She buys the palm fruit in nearby communities. Margaret has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy palm fruits in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy palm fruit

loans.name: Irma

texts.en: Irma B. is from the village of Sto. Nino, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old and is married. Irma owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling a variety of different products including pillow cases and curtains in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In September 2009, Irma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family’s income. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Koffi Hyppo

texts.fr: Cet homme habite le quartier d’Anfamé à Lomé ; il n’est pas marié et n’a aucun enfant à sa charge. Pour se prendre en charge, il exerce comme activité génératrice de revenus la vente de matériels électriques à son domicile. Il a appris le métier d’électricité, plus précisément il est monteur électricien. C’est en 2007 qu’il s’est lancé dans la vente de matériels électroniques pour pourvoir aussi gagner une clientèle sur le terrain. A présent il est connu de beaucoup de personnes qui apprécient son travail toujours bien fait et qui sait bien accueillir sa clientèle. Il a un besoin pressant en ce moment de renouveler son stock électrique ; pour cette raison, il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter des rouleaux de fils électriques et divers autres matériels indispensables.

loans.use: Achat de matériels électriques

loans.name: Tsagaan

texts.en: Tsagaan Narantsetseg is 55 years old and lives with her husband and two children in a house in Bayanhongor province in central Mongolia. She currently operates a grocery trading business out of a shipping container at a local market. To supplement her earnings, she also has a billiards table in front of the container so customers can stop and play while they shop. Narantsetseg started her business in 1995 with her capital of 300,000 tugrugs. She has gained much selling experience and knowledge of her trade over the years, and attributes her success to her good accounting skills. Today, her working capital exceeds 700,000 tugrugs. In the future, she hopes to grow her business and move out of her shipping container, which is a very uncomfortable workplace. She says, "I hope to own a stall in the trading center where I can work comfortably." She also plans to use her future earnings to remodel her house. Narantsetseg is requesting a 550,000 tugrug loan in order to purchase more grocery products to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell

loans.name: Chab

texts.en:
Mrs. Chab L. lives in Chuos village in Takeo province. She is a 24 years old and is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this, she also sells rice soup in the village. Her husband, Mr. Maong Phearum, helps her in the business.

Although they try to work hard, they still earn less income than needed to support their family living. Thus, Mrs. Chab L. decided to ask for a loan to buy ten more piglets to raise. This couple does not have any children. Her husband is shown with her in the photo.

loans.use: To buy ten more piglets to raise

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng S., 36, is single and resides in Battambong Province, Cambodia, with one of her brothers. To make a living, she is engaged in a business of selling a few kinds of vegetables at a local market, earning a gross income of $20 per day. Her brother helps her in the business by using his bicycle to transport the vegetables to the market every day. 

S. and her brother are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorbike to easily transport vegetables for sale.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob O. is 37 years old, married with two children, 1 and 3 years old. His wife sells tubers of yam to support the home. He is an LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and Africa.

Jacob O. sells medicines, groceries and drinks at retail prices to make a living. He lives in Delta state, Nigeria. With these combined businesses, he hopes to meet the basic needs of his family. He hopes for a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase medicine, groceries and drinks to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase medicine, groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: A. Bernadette est née en 1961 et vit depuis 18 ans à Davatin dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à DOHETO Honoré, un cuisinier, Bernadette est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Il n’y a que trois des enfants qui soient à sa charge. La famille vit ensemble à Davatin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Bernadette n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Bernadette vend divers produits de beauté (lait corporel, eau de toilette, savons, déodorants, parfums etc.) de façon ambulante. Bernadette mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de «sodabi» (boisson alcoolisée locale) à son domicile. Bernadette s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Bernadette est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits auprès de l’institution. Bernadette a bien remboursé les quatre crédits qu’elle a obtenus de ALIDé. Bernadette sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’accroître son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande des clients.
texts.en:
Bernadette A. was born in 1961 and has been living for the past 18 years in the Davatin area of Sèmè-Podji, in Benin. She is married to Honoré DOHETO, a cook, and is mother of five children, all educated, of which three are still in her care. The family lives together in Davatin, and the couple share household expenses. Bernadette has not attended school. To meet her own and her children's needs, Bernadette sells a variety of beauty products (body lotion, eau de toilette, soaps, deodorants, perfumes, etc.) as an itinerant vendor. Bernadette's second business activity is selling "sodabi" (a local alcoholic beverage) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Bernadette is a former client of ALIDé, having previously been granted four loans with the organisation, all of which have been fully reimbursed. She now requests a fifth loan from ALIDé, to increase her activities and better respond to her customer's needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy boxes of beauty products (body lotions, beauty soaps, perfumes, deodorants, powders)

loans.name: Sokhan

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhan K. is a farmer who owns a piece of land to grow rice and crops to support her family. She is 42 years old and lives in Preaek Ta Nob village in Kandal Province. She is the mother of four children: two are attending the local public school while the other two are too young for school. Her husband, Mr. Vout Phuong, is a fisherman and has another job as a palm juice collector (he is on the left in the photo). 

This family now faces some obstacles with their rice field. Thus, Mrs. Sokhan K. decided to apply for a loan to purchase additional hoses to water her crops.

loans.use: To purchase additional hoses

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en: Reynaldo D., 39 years old, is engaged in fish retail. He is a fisherman and he raises his family by selling his own catch. He also buys fish from other fishermen and resells it to the next town. He started his business when he was just a teenager since he learned how to fish at a very early age.  He joined CEVI in 2009 and likes the program. This is the reason why he would like to re-apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will really help him obtain more fish to resell.

loans.use: To buy fish to resell

loans.name: Nilza Augusto

texts.pt:
Nilza Augusto S. nasceu na cidade da Matola, provincia de  Maputo, sul deMoçambique tem 23 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 2 filhos de 04 e 01 anos de idade, destes ninguem vai a escola . fez somente 10ą classe parou com os estudos devido a gravidez precoce. Vive na casa própria com a sua família, o marido é trabalhador da empresa Electricidade de Moçambique . Para alem da sua familia nao sustenta mais ninguem.
Saiu  da Matola para o Distrito de Boane com a sua familia no ano de 2005, a quando da transferencia do marido pela sua empresa. Tem um negócio próprio há mais de 3 anos, este actividade desenvolve no quintal da sua casa, trabalha das 7horas ate as 17 horas todos os dias e não possui nenhum empregado. Neste negocio consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.000.00mt por mes, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum atravez de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa ).
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através da sua prima que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas, barrotes, cimento e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt ambos para  a mesma actividade.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este emprestimo tambem, para poder aceder a outros creditos. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para a conclusao da sua obra e oferecer melhor conforto a sua familia.
texts.en:
Nilza Augusto was born in the city of Matola, in the Maputo Province, in the South of Mozambique. She is 23 years old, married and the mother of a 1-year old and a 4-year old. None of the children are in school. She only went to school until the 10th grade due to a teen pregnancy. She owns the house she lives in with her family. Her husband works for Mozambique Power Company. She doesn't support anyone other than her own family. In 2005, she left Matola for the Boane District with her family. Her husband was transferred there by his employer. She has had her own business in her backyard for over 3 years. She works from 7am to 5pm everyday and has no employees. Her business brings an income of around 3.000.00mt a month which goes towards house expenses and a traditional rotational savings system (Xitique). She has never had loans from other banks. She came to know about Hluvuku through her cousin who is also a member. This loan, in the amount of 25.000.00mt, is her third. She intends to building materials (screens, beams, cement and others) to continue building her house. The previous loans were for 6.000.00mt and15.000.00mt and were used for the same purpose. She makes a commitment to pay this loan on time, to be able to be granted further credit. In the future, she would like to request more loans to finish her house and offer more comfort to her family.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of building materials

loans.name: Jotham

texts.en: Jotham thanks God for his 2.5-hectare rice field that he currently tills. He said it has been his family's source of income for years now. He spends most of his time at the farm, because he has goals to achieve. He has children who go to school, and he wants them to finish college and have a bright future. He currently needs additional capital for his farm. So, he applied for a loan from CEVI. He said that with the amount of 6000 PHP, he would be able to buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farm supplies he needs.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farm supplies

loans.name: Marie Gay Rose's Group

texts.en:
Marie Gay Rose R. is from the village of Magsaysay. She is 42 years old. Marie Gay Rose is the group leader for a 13-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Marie Gay Rose R. Group.

Marie Gay Rose is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Marie Gay Rose owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marie Gay Rose has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Marie Gay Rose joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marie Gay Rose has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marie Gay Rose is requesting a new loan of 19,000 PHP, which will also be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Irenea

texts.es:
La Sra. Irinea C. tiene 48 años D. edad, está casada hace mas D. 12 años, tiene 7 hijos D. los cuales 5 aun dependen económicamente D. ella, a través D. su actividad que se refiere al servicio D. comida, que ofrece a los niños del Colegio Marcelo Quiroga Santa Cruz, aprovechando los horarios D. descanso D. estos ("El recreo"),  para vender. Esta su actividad la ayudado a lograr que 2 D. sus hijos salgan bachilleres y puedan independizase, además D. proseguir con sus estudios superiores y D. esta manera mejor su calidad D. vida. 

El crédito que solicita la Sra. Irinea le ayudara a incrementar y mejorar su servicio ofreciendo comida no solo en el colegio, también a comensales D. la población lo que incrementara sus ingresos para D. igual manera que sus 2 hijos, los 5 restantes puedan contar con una educación superior.
texts.en:
Mrs. Irinea C. is 48 years old, she has been married for more than 12 years, and has 7 children of which 5 are still her dependants. She sells food to the children of the school Colegio Marcelo Quiroga Santa Cruz during their recess (“el recreo”) schedule. Her business has helped with two of her children graduating from high school, becoming independent, continuing with higher education and improving their quality of life. Mrs. Irinea is requesting the loan to help her increase and improve the business by selling food not only to the school but also to other customers in town; she hopes this will increase her income and like her first 2 children, the remaining 5 can get a higher education.

Translated from Spanish by Carlos Morales, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Massajja C Kakembo Mariam Group

texts.en: K. Mariam is 45 years old, widowed, and a mother of five children. She has been running a charcoal business for over ten years. She is using her loan to purchase charcoal from villages to sell in town. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal from villages to sell in town

loans.name: New Hope Group

texts.es:
Martha se dedica a diversos tipos D. negocios que le permiten mantener a su familia, ella cria y venD. aves D. corral como son pollos, patos y otros animals D. corral. Ademas venD. desayuno por las mañanas en un Mercado. Asimismo prepara humitas y tamales cuando lo solicitan ella se esfuerza mucho ya que desea invertir en la profesion D. sus hijos.
Sebastiana cria y venD. cerdos hace varios años con sus pocos ingresos desea mejorar sus criaderos y multiplicar sus cerditos para asi obtener mayors ganancias.
La secretaria Juana tiene un pequeño colegio primario donD. labora como docente, ella tiene 1 hijo, por el cual se esfuerza, ya que es su unico ingreso.
Los socios agradecen los prestamos y estan seguros D. que con esfuerzo pueden construir sus sueños. About EDAPROSPO: EDAPROSPO seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty
texts.en:
Martha works at many different businesses that allow her to support her family. She raises and sells birds, like chickens, ducks, and other types of fowl. She also sells breakfast at the market in the morning. She prepares humitas (flavored corn paste wrapped in corn leaves) and tamales when they are requested. She works very hard because she would like to invest in her children's occupation. Sebastiana has raised and sold pigs for many years with her small income. She wants to improve her farm and increase the number of piglets she has in order to earn more money. The secretary, Juana, has a small primary school where she works as a teacher. She has one child, who is the reason she works so hard since that is her only income. The members are grateful for the loans and are sure that with effort they can build their dreams. About EDAPROSPO: EDAPROSPO seeks to use micro-credit to foster productive commercial activity for the sake of economic and social development within vulnerable urban and rural sectors traditionally neglected by commercial banks. By offering innovative products such as technical education loans and microfinance groups for young persons, EDAPROSPO helps disadvantaged Peruvians lift themselves out of poverty

Translated from Spanish by Eileen Gessner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improve agricultural businesses, food vending, and schools

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es: Silvia Solórzano C., tiene la edad de 33 años, es divorciada, y vive  con sus tres hijos de 9,5  años de edad y su bebé de 3 meses de nacido. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de inventario para su negocio. Desea tener un inventario más amplio y variado de productos para ofrecer en local. Ella se dedica a la venta de productos naturales. Tiene varios años de haber empezado con este negocio, y cuenta con muy buenos clientes, por eso ve la necesidad de ofrecer mayor variedad de productos en el mismo, además de aportar mayores ingresos para la economía de su hogar. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy agradecida con las facilidades que se le han brindado siempre. Ella espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como comerciante.
texts.en:
Silvia Solórzano C. is 33 years old, and she is divorced. She lives with her three children; 9 years old, 5 years old, and a three month old baby. She wants the loan to buy inventory for her business. She wants to have more inventory and a variety of products to sell at her place of business. She sells natural products. She started this business several years ago. She has very good customers. Therefore, she sees the need to offer a greater variety of products. This will provide greater income for the economy of her household. This is her first loan with FUDECOSUR, and she is very happy with the terms of the loan she got. In the future she hopes to give her family a better quality of life and greater economic stability. She also wants to be able to keep growing as a person and a businesswoman.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Natural products

loans.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen T., 47, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Perigryn T., a driver, and they are blessed with six children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own piggery while overseeing their slipper-making business. She also owns a clothing store and a hot dog / hamburger stand.

Carmen has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT)* for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the success of her business, Carmen would like to apply for an 18,000 Philippine peso loan. This money will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding business to buy more products for her clothing and snack stand. She will also invest some of the loan into buying feed for her swine and raw materials for their slipper business. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To bug more products for a clothing and snack stand and for hog feed and raw materials for a slipper business

loans.name: Marie Louise

texts.en:
Marie Louise was born in 1977, and she is a widow with two children, 7 and 9; both are in school. Marie Louise takes care of four dependents these days. She employs two people from her community as helpers so that her business runs well. The hours of her daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day.

Marie Louise is now requesting a second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business which is very important for her and for her community because she will be able to satisfy her customers. Once this happens, Marie Louise will be able to earn more profit. With extra profits, she will save money for her children.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Tiessiri  4 Group

texts.fr:
TIESSIRI 4  est un regroupement de femmes mariées du village de N’TION dans la préfecture de SAN, région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali), qui vivent dans des familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 26    ans, 4 enfants et cultivent de l’arachide.   
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso cette année et sont à leur premier prêt de campagne.
BINTOU T. compte utiliser son  prêt pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels agricoles et des intrants, au grand marché de TENE. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de TENE, MOPTI et dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 21500à 33000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The Tiessiri 1 group consists of married women from the village of N'tion in the prefecture of San, Segou region (Mali's Fourth Administrative District). They live in traditional families. On average, each is 26 and has four children. They are peanut farmers. Hoping to make more profit from farming, the group decided to sign up with Soro Yiriwaso this year, and are receiving their first operational loan. Bintou T. plans to use her loan to buy seed peanuts, small tools, and fertilizer at the big market in Tene. After the rains end, the harvest is stored long enough to increase in value and be sold in the big market of Tene, Mopti and in nearby markets at retail (often, wholesale) to customers who mostly come from large towns. Each member of the group is counting on making a profit of between 21,500 and 33,000 CFA after their produce is sold. They will use the money to pay loan interest and day-to-day family expenses.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer, seed and small tools

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah is married with five children and all of them are at school. She also takes care of additional family members.  She owns a stall in Bwaise selling bananas. She has been in this banana business for over ten years.  She buys bunches of bananas at her place of work and so doesn’t pay transport costs.  She plans to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  Apart from this banana business she doesn’t have any other side business. 

Aidah sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale and receives an average of 25 customers a day. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living.  Her greatest business challenge is seasonality because she works in a muddy place and this hinders her customers to reach her.  

Aidah is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and starting going to farmers directly.  Aidah joined MCDT because of low interest charged.  She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a computer and to maintain the cyber café.

loans.name: Pang

texts.en:
Pang S. is 57 years of age and resides in Phnom Penh.  In order to meet the needs of the family, she sells groceries inside the local market.  Pang has been in business for four years and earns approximately $5 per day. 

She is a single mother blessed to a son who decorates wedding halls.  Her daughter-in-law is a tailor.  Pang will be used her loan to buy merchandise to resell.  This will help her increase her income to ensure her entire family will have a good standard of living.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to resell.

loans.name: Nazgul's Group

texts.en:
Nazgul R. is the leader of the group. She is twenty-seven and married. She has a six-year-old son, who goes to kindergarten. Her husband is a taxi driver. She is a manager at the local kindergarten. Seven years ago, her parents gave her cattle and she decided to start a business breeding cattle. For now, she has been able to increase cattle quantity, purchase household appliances and computer and make capital repairs of her house. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase additional cattle for breeding. 

In the future, she is planning to purchase a car for her family. 

Group members:

Nurgul T. is the treasurer of the group. She is thirty-six and married. She has four children: her two elder sons and daughter go to school and her youngest son is at home. She is an accountant. Two years ago, her parents gave her cattle and she started breeding cattle. She has been able to increase the number of cattle and make capital repairs of her house. She is applying for a loan in order to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the near future, she is planning to widen shed for cattle.

Bubusaira D. is forty-three and divorced. She has two daughters, aged fifteen and nine, both of whom go to school. She sells convenience goods at her own shop. She started seven years ago with initial investment of 200 soms. Before that, she sold convenience goods on a table near to her house. Day by day, she has been able to increase her turnover. For now, she could build a shop. She is applying for a loan in order to increase her turnover. 

Zamira Z. is thirty-four and married. She has three sons, aged fourteen, twelve and seven. Her husband works in construction. She sells vegetables at the local market. She started five years ago with financial support of her husband in the amount of 500 soms. Then, her business became profitable. She increased her turnover and was able to purchase household appliances. She is applying for a loan in order to increase her turnover further. In the future, she is planning to diversify the assortment of goods.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan.
